questions.text: Eustachian tube function is best assessed by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tympanometry machine comes with a special function of assessment of Eustachian tube function. Politzerisation is done with politzer bag whose tip is kept at nostril and bag is deflated. olive-shaped tip of Politzer bag

questions.text: A 14 years boy presents with nasal obstruction, proptosis (Fig),recurrent epistaxis from 3–4 years not responding to anterior nasal packing. Which artery is source of bleeding
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Internal maxillary artery. A 14-year-old boy with nasal obstruction, proptosis, and recurrent epistaxis that is not responding to anterior nasal packing is highly suggestive of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA). Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA): Benign but highly vascular tumor that occurs exclusively in adolescent males. Arises from the sphenopalatine foramen in the posterolateral wall of the nasal cavity. Presents with recurrent, profuse epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and proptosis due to tumor extension into the orbit. Source of Bleeding – Internal Maxillary Artery (IMA): The Internal Maxillary Artery (IMA) is the main blood supply to JNA. It gives rise to the sphenopalatine artery, which is the major contributor to nasal mucosal vascularization. Since JNA is highly vascular, it is crucial to embolize the internal maxillary artery before surgical excision to reduce intraoperative bleeding. Incorrect Options: (B) Ascending pharyngeal artery This artery is a branch of the external carotid artery and contributes to the blood supply of the pharynx and skull base, but it is not the primary source of bleeding in JNA. (C) Facial artery The facial artery supplies the external structures of the face and contributes to the superficial vasculature of the nose but is not the primary source of bleeding in JNA. (D) Anterior ethmoidal artery The anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery (from the internal carotid system) and supplies the anterior nasal septum and lateral nasal wall. It is involved in epistaxis from the anterior septum (Kiesselbach’s plexus) but not in JNA, which originates deeper in the nasal cavity.

questions.text: Topical treatment forrecurrent respiratory papillomatosis includes
questions.solution: B Intralesional Cidofovir is used to decrease the recurrence rate. Other agents are interferon alpha and indole 3 carbinol

questions.text: Kashima operation is done for
questions.solution: A This surgery is done in abductor palsy. Co2 laser is used to separate the membranous and cartilaginous part of vocal cord.

questions.text: A Patients presents to your clinic for evaluation of defective hearing. Rinnie’s test shows air conduction greater than the bone conduction on both sides with Weber test Lateralized to right ear. What is the next logical step?
questions.solution: b. Schwabach’s test Schawbach and ABC test both are used to test the functioning of cochlea. To give proper meaning to Rinne and weber test findings, they should be followed by either of these .

questions.text: Which is the most common type of congenital ossicular dysfunction?
questions.solution: b. Stapes defect with fixation of footplate and lenticular process involvement

questions.text: Which of the following tests is recommended for neonatal screening of hearing?
questions.solution: c. Evoked OAE Hearing screening in non high risk group is primarily done with OAE. However in high risk babies e.g. NICU babies, it is done using BERA preferably automated.

questions.text: All of the following instruments are required for tonsillectomy except :
questions.solution: c. Suction diathermy Suction diathermy is a method of adenoidectomy

questions.text: A 45 year old lady presented with complaints of nasal congestion , stuffiness ,discharge and anosmia . CT scan of paranasal sinus was done as shown below what is the diagnosis :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Allergic Fungal Sinusitis is the diagnosis. This condition is the most common type of fungal sinusitis, typically seen in patients presenting with nasal congestion, stuffiness, discharge, and anosmia. It results from type I and III hypersensitivity reactions to fungal antigens, most commonly Aspergillus fumigatus. On CT scans, allergic fungal sinusitis is characterized by heterogeneous opacification of the sinuses due to the presence of allergic mucin mixed with fungal debris and nasal polyps. The management involves functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) combined with corticosteroids, while antifungals are reserved for invasive fungal sinusitis rather than the allergic type. Incorrect Responses: (A) Ethmoidal Polyp – This option is less likely because ethmoidal polyps typically present as homogeneously opacified soft tissue masses on CT scans and are usually associated with chronic rhinosinusitis rather than the heterogeneous appearance seen in allergic fungal sinusitis. (B) Antrochonal Polyp – An antrochoanal polyp is usually a unilateral, benign lesion arising from the maxillary sinus and extending into the nasopharynx. Its imaging features and clinical presentation differ from the bilateral, heterogeneous opacification typical of allergic fungal sinusitis. (D) Nasoethmoidal Carcinoma – Carcinoma in the nasoethmoidal region would likely present with more aggressive features such as bone destruction and localized mass effect, rather than the characteristic allergic mucin and heterogeneous sinus opacification seen in allergic fungal sinusitis.

questions.text: Identify the encircled structure in middle ear cavity :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sinus tympani It is between ponticulus and subiculum .. these two spicules are visible in the picture. Its an area of residual cholesteatoma after mastoid surgery

questions.text: 5 year old child presents with voice change and stirdor Identify the abnormality marked on the fiberoptic laryngoscopy:
questions.solution: B Respiratory papillomatosis Juvenile papillomas are caused by HPV-6,11. The infection is transmitted from mother at the time of birth. They can spread downwards to trachea bronchi lungs. CO2 laser is the treatment of choice. Recurrences are common after surgery. are premalignant Interferon alpha and intralesional cidovofir is helpful in management. In case of respiratory distress in a patient of juvenile papilloma, tracheostomy should be done. Intubation will lead to spread of disease to trachea, bronchi. All papillomas should be examined histopathologically to exclude any dysplastic features or malignant transformation.

questions.text: A construction worker met with an accident and presented to the trauma centre when a heavy concrete block fell over his face. He was found to have severe maxillofacial and laryngeal injury. He was not able to open his mouth and, on examination, he is found to have multiple fractures and obstruction in patent airway, the following procedure was done for him. Which of the following options correct define the procedure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cricothyroidotomy. In this case, the patient has sustained severe maxillofacial and laryngeal injuries, which have resulted in an obstruction in the patent airway and an inability to open the mouth. Given these conditions, a cricothyroidotomy would be the most appropriate emergency procedure to secure the airway. Cricothyroidotomy involves making an incision through the cricothyroid membrane to establish an airway when other methods of securing the airway, such as orotracheal intubation, are not possible due to facial or laryngeal trauma. This procedure is especially indicated in situations of severe facial trauma where access to the mouth or nose is compromised. Incorrect Options: (A) Submental endotracheal intubation This technique involves placing an endotracheal tube through a submental incision, providing an airway when there is maxillofacial trauma. However, it is not the most common or immediate procedure performed in cases of airway obstruction due to traumatic injury. A cricothyroidotomy is preferred when rapid airway access is needed. (B) Emergency tracheostomy An emergency tracheostomy is typically performed when prolonged airway management is needed, or if other less invasive procedures have failed. However, cricothyroidotomy is preferred in the acute setting due to its faster execution and lower complication rate compared to tracheostomy. (D) Subcutaneous tracheostomy This is an uncommon procedure and not typically used in emergency airway management. A subcutaneous tracheostomy would involve placing a tracheostomy tube beneath the skin, but this is not the standard technique in traumatic airway obstructions where cricothyroidotomy is preferred.

questions.text: According to the WHO definition of hearing loss, what is the value to classify as profound hearing loss?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) >81 dB

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnosis on the audiogram shown below?
questions.solution: . (a) Otosclerosis Carhart’s notch in audiogram is at 2000 Hz in BC curve. It disappears after stapes surgery overclosure The mechanism of carhart’s notch is not well understood . the proposed mechanism is that some part of bone conducted sound also travels through the ossicles . in otosclerosis as ossicular inertia increase, so there is problem in bone conduction of sound as well and as the middle ear resonance is at 2000 Hz therefore this phenomenon is most marked at 2000 Hz and hence carhart’s notch appears at this frequency in BC curve.

questions.text: A 6-years-old with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory distress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution: (d) Respiratory papillomatosis Juvenile papillomas are caused by HPV-6,11. The infection is transmitted from mother at the time of birth.They can spread downwards to trachea bronchi lungs. CO2 laser is the treatment of choice. Recurrences are common after surgery. are premalignant Interferon alpha and intralesional cidovofir is helpful in management. In case of respiratory distress in a patient of juvenile papilloma, tracheostomy should be done. Intubation will lead to spread of disease to trachea, bronchi. All papillomas should be examined histopathologically to exclude any dysplastic features or malignant transformation.

questions.text: Identify the following line shown in the below picture
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ohngren line Ohngren’s line is from medial canthus of the eye to the angle of mandible. This line divides maxilla into superstructure and infrastructure. The malignancy of superstructure has poor prognosis due to proximity to orbit.

questions.text: Which of the following is not ligated in case of epistaxis control?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Internal carotid artery. The internal carotid artery (ICA) is not ligated in the management of epistaxis because it is a major artery supplying the brain, and ligating it could lead to severe complications like stroke or neurological deficits. While branches of the internal carotid artery (such as the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries) may be involved in epistaxis, direct ligation of the ICA itself is not an option. Instead, embolization of its branches may be performed if necessary. Incorrect Options: A. Anterior Ethmoidal Artery – Can Be Ligated The anterior ethmoidal artery, a branch of the ophthalmic artery (from the internal carotid system), supplies the anterior and superior nasal septum. In cases of severe anterior epistaxis, this artery can be ligated via an external approach through the medial orbit. B. Maxillary Artery – Can Be Ligated The maxillary artery, a branch of the external carotid artery, is the main supplier of the posterior nasal cavity through its terminal branch, the sphenopalatine artery. It is frequently ligated in posterior epistaxis through an intraoral (transantral) or endoscopic approach. C. External Carotid Artery – Can Be Ligated The external carotid artery gives off the maxillary artery, which is a major contributor to nasal bleeding. In severe, intractable epistaxis, especially when other measures fail, the external carotid artery may be ligated to reduce blood flow to the nasal mucosa.

questions.text: An intraoperative photograph of cortical mastoidectomy. Which of the following is the lateral semi-circular canal?
questions.solution: B Lateral semicircular canal is a whitish bulge on the floor of mastoid antrum A --- facial nerve C --- sino-dural angle (Citelli's angle) D --- sigmoid plate

questions.text: Which facial sinus continues to grow even in adulthood?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The frontal sinus continues to grow even into adulthood. It typically begins to develop around 6 years of age and reaches full size after puberty, but subtle growth can continue even in adulthood. Incorrect options: B. Maxillary: The maxillary sinus is the first to develop and is well-formed even at birth. Most of its growth occurs in early childhood and is generally complete by adolescence. C. Ethmoid: The ethmoid sinuses are also present at birth and complete their growth by puberty. D. Sphenoid: The sphenoid sinuses begin to develop around 3 years of age and typically finish growing by the late teenage years.

questions.text: The patient came with an ulcer on the side of the nose as shown, which bleeds on itching. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: B

choices.text: Septal branch of the superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of the following arteries of the Kiesselbach’s plexus is not a branch of ECA.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ethmoidal arteries are branches of ICA. Rest are branches of ECA.

questions.text: Target sign is seen in a blot test from nasal discharge in which of these conditions.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Traumatic CSF Leak (Correct Answer) The target sign (also called the halo sign or double-ring sign) is seen in a blot test performed on nasal discharge to differentiate CSF rhinorrhea from normal nasal secretions or blood. When a drop of fluid is placed on a piece of filter paper or gauze, CSF forms a clear outer ring, while blood (if present) stays in the center, creating a bullseye or target-like appearance. Traumatic CSF leaks occur due to skull base fractures, particularly involving the cribriform plate or temporal bone, leading to nasal or otorrheal CSF leakage. Incorrect Options: (B) Fracture Mastoid A mastoid fracture can lead to CSF otorrhea (CSF leakage from the ear), rather than nasal discharge. The target sign is typically used for nasal CSF leaks, making this less relevant for mastoid fractures. (C) Spontaneous CSF Leak Spontaneous CSF leaks occur due to idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) or congenital skull base defects, often without a history of trauma. While a target sign can still be seen in these cases, it is most commonly associated with traumatic leaks, making Option A the better choice. (D) Meningoencephalocele A meningoencephalocele is a herniation of brain tissue and meninges through a skull defect, which can cause intermittent CSF leakage. While CSF rhinorrhea can occur, the target sign is more frequently used in cases of acute traumatic leaks.

questions.text: A steel factory worker is suffering from noise induced hearing loss. Which of the following is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Inner hair cells --- are 3500 in number , arranged in one row, flask shaped, transmit auditory stimuli ( mainly afferent) and are more resistant Oute hair cells--- 12000 in number, in 3 or 4 rows, cylindrical in shape. They are primarily efferent. Their function is to modulate the function of inner hair cells. They are vulnerable to sound and drugs.

questions.text: Gelles test is done in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gelles test is done for conductive deafness to evaluate for bone conduction • Increase the pressure in the external auditory meatus • Normal or SNHL: There will be decrease in loudness from bone conducted stimulus • Fixation of stapes like in case of otosclerosis: No alteration of bone conduction

questions.text: Best surgery to relieve intractable vertigo in a menieres disease patient is?

questions.text: A 12 years adolescent male presents with unilateral mass in nose with recurrent spontaneous bleeding. On examination a pink mass covered with mucosa is found in the nasopharynx. Which of the following is not to be done?
questions.solution: A The clinical history given above points towards angiofibroma. It is a destructive tumour diagnosed on CT. • hollman millers sign seen on ct in which posterior wall of maxillary sinus is being pushed forward by the tumour. This sing is also called antral sign • frog face deformity is seen . • treatment is radiotherapy followed by surgery. Endoscopic surgery and angioembolisation can be done. • Biopsy is never done. • since highly vascular tumor, biopsy can cause torrential bleeding

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to taste?

questions.text: A middle aged while turning on side of his bed has a sensation of severe vertigo. Most probable diagnosis is ?

The virus responsible for this condition is HPV 11 > 6. It is commonly of two types • Juvenile : always multiple, resolve spontaneously , recur spontaneously • Senile: they are single, never resolve spontaneously, never recur

Inorder to lateralise them, type 2 thyroplasty is used. Other methods to lateralize are :cordectomies, arytenoidectomy. Cordectomies are of three types Open method Endoscopic cordectomy CO2 cordectomy :kashima operation Arytenoidectomy is of two types Open arytenoidectomy: woodman procedure Endoscopic arytenoidectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is the neurotransmitter for inner hair cells
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- B Neurotransmission of cochlear inner hair cell synapse – ikmplications for inner ear therapy Cochlear inner hair cells are connected to afferent type I auditory neurons and use probably L-glutamate as neurotransmitter

questions.text: Which of the following is the safe limit of noise levels in a city
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- C WHO limit of industries is not beyond > 85 dB for noise induced damage WHO limit for safe limit of noise levels in city is 45 dB

questions.text: Pathology shown in given coronal CT scan slice should be corrected by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Open reduction after 3 weeks In cases of fractures involving the facial bones, particularly the zygoma, orbit, or maxilla, open reduction timing is crucial. Waiting for 3 weeks allows for initial swelling to subside, making surgical correction more precise and reducing complications. After 3 weeks, fibrous union may begin, but complete bony healing has not yet occurred, making reduction still possible without extensive osteotomy. This approach is often recommended for zygomaticomaxillary complex (ZMC) fractures, nasal fractures, and mandibular fractures in select cases. Incorrect Options: (A) Open reduction immediately Immediate surgery is only considered in cases of severe displacement, ocular involvement (diplopia, enophthalmos), or airway compromise. Otherwise, early surgery may be difficult due to severe edema, which can obscure surgical landmarks. (B) Open reduction after 3 days Three days is often too early, as swelling may still be significant, leading to difficulties in precise fracture reduction. Surgeons usually prefer to wait 7–10 days for swelling to improve before performing open reduction. (D) Open reduction after 3 months Three months is too late, as bony healing and remodeling would have progressed, making reduction much more difficult. At this stage, osteotomies and more extensive surgical intervention may be required.

questions.solution: C Pterygopalatine fossa communicates laterally with infra temporal fossa via pterygopalatine fissure

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is injured in the pyriform fossa while taking out a fish bone?
questions.solution: A Pyriform fossa is a part of hypopharynx which surrounds the larynx from both sides. It is the most common site for hypopharyngeal malignancy and it is crossed by internal laryngeal nerve.

questions.solution: C Types of tracheoesophageal fistula are

choices.text: Long term use of steroids may be causative
Steroids may produce inflammation and hypertrophy of turbinates predisposing to this
Long term use of alpha adrenergic agonists may be causative
May be produced by cocaine sniffing
Only 5-10% may regress despite high-dose steroids

questions.text: True regarding rhinitis medicamentosa and its associations is/are?
questions.solution: CD Ref:Sataloff's Comprehensive Textbook of Otolaryngology: Head & Neck Surgery, Vol 2/297-302; Dhingra 6th Ed/170 Explanation: Rhinitis medicamentosa The term indicates “persistent rhinitis induced by prolonged use of topical nasal decongestants (sympathomimetic amines and imidazoles)” (Task force definition). It is classified as “non-allergic rhinitis” (Old PGI MCQ) Mostly caused by topical sympathetic agents (e.g. alpha-adrenergic agonists like xylometazoline) May rarely be produced by cocaine sniffing and benzalkonium chloride. Persistent adrenergic stimulation producing refractoriness and rebound vasodilatation may be the pathophysiology After use of topical sympathetic agents beyond 3-5 days, there is rebound vasodilatation, nasal obstruction, edema, erythema and reduced efficacy of the drug. This congestion causes the patient to increase the frequency of application and the quantity applied, resulting in dependence on topical nasal decongestants Clinical rhinoscopic examination is non-specific, showing areas of red, thickened mucosa and dull zones It is treated by withdrawal of nasal drops, short course of systemic steroid therapy and in some cases, surgical reduction of turbinates, if they have become hypertrophied (Dhingra) Both topical and systemic steroids are effective in most cases. Topical antihistamines may also be tried (Sataloff”s)

choices.text: Paraesthesia due to facial nerve injury

questions.text: Features seen with malar fracture of zygomatic bone may include?
questions.solution: ABD Ref: Dhingra 5th Ed/197 Explanation: Clinical features of zygoma fracture • Swelling over zygomatic arch • Flattening of cheeks/malar prominence • Step-deformity in infraorbital margins • Anesthesia in IO nerve distribution • Trismus • Oblique palpebral fissure • Diplopia due to reduced ocular movements • Periorbital emphysema • Ipsilateral epistaxis rarely

choices.text: Ossicular chain disruption leads to painful conductive deafness

questions.text: True regarding otosclerosis is/are?
questions.solution: AC Ref: Dhingra 5th Ed/97-100 Explanation: Otosclerosis • Normal enchodral bone is replaced by irregular spongy bone in the bony otic capsule • Many cases show AD inheritance with incomplete penetrance • Females > Males, Whites > Negroes • MC site: Promontory near the anterior margin of the oval window. Stapes involved in late cases • Bilateral conductive hearing loss, painless and progressive • Paracusis willissii: Better hearing in noisy surroundings • Mobile TM, FLmaingo-pink blush/hue through the TM: Schwartz sign

choices.text: Maxillary nerve block is not done since always done under GA
Done for biopsy in antral malignancy

questions.text: Correct statement(s) regarding Caldwell-Luc operation?
questions.solution: ACDE Ref: Dhingra 5th Ed/422 Explanation: Caldwell-Luc operation Caldwell-Luc operation is a process of opening the maxillary antrum through canine fossa by sub-labial approach and dealing with the pathology inside the antrum. Can be done under LA. Indications: Chronic maxillary sinusitis with irreversible changes in the sinus mucosa. Removal of foreign bodies or root of a tooth. Dental cyst. Oroantral fistula. Suspected neoplasm in the antrum and its biopsy. Recurrent antrochoanal polyp. Fracture of maxilla or blow-out fractures of the orbit. As an approach to ethmoids (Horgan's transantral ethmoidectomy). Approach to pterygopalatine fossa for ligation of maxillary artery. Vidian neurectomy. Complications: Post-operative bleeding. This can be controlled by nasal pack. Anaesthesia of the cheek due to stretching of infraorbital nerve. It may last for a few weeks or months. Anaesthesia of teeth. Injury to nasolacrimal duct. Sublabial fistula. Osteomyelitis of maxilla (rare).

choices.text: To test fatiguability of nerve in retrocochlear lesions

questions.text: Tone decay test is used to identify which among the following condition (s)?
questions.solution: ABE Ref: Dhingra 5th Ed/31, Logan and Turner Explanation: Threshold tone decay test test It is a measure of nerve fatigue and is used to detect retrocochlear lesions. Normally, a person can hear a tone continuously for 60 seconds. Innerve fatigue, he stops hearing earlier. The threshold tone decay test is simple and is performed in the following manner:A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above the patient's threshold of hearing, continuously for a period of 60 seconds. If patient stops hearingearlier, intensity is increased by another 5 dB. The procedure is continued till patient can hear the tone continuously for 60 seconds, or no level exists above the threshold where tone is audible for full 60 seconds. The result is expressed as number of dB of decay. A decay more than 25 dBis diagnostic of a retrocochlear lesion.

choices.text: Risk of recurrent meningitis in childhood

questions.text: True regarding Mondini’s disease/dysplasia is/are?
questions.solution: ABCDE Explanation: Mondini dysplasia is a type of inner ear malformation that is present at birth (congenital). Individuals with Mondini dysplasia have one and a half coils of the cochlea instead of the normal two coils. It may occur in one ear (unilateral) or both ears (bilateral) and can cause varying degrees of sensorineural hearing loss, although most individuals have profound hearing loss. The condition can also predispose affected individuals to recurrent meningitis. It is caused by disruption in the embryonic development of the inner ear during the seventh week of gestation. Surgery is followed by the use of cochlear implants to treat patients with inner ear malformations

questions.text: True regarding ludwig’s angina is/are? A. Associated with diabetes mellitus B. Pus collection below the tongue pushes it upwards C. Associated with sialolithiasis D. Bilateral lymphadenopathy may occur E. Swelling and erythema below the chin
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A. Associated with diabetes mellitus True. Ludwig’s angina is more common and more severe in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. B. Pus collection below the tongue pushes it upwards True. Infection of the submandibular, sublingual, and submental spaces leads to elevation of the tongue, which can cause airway obstruction — a hallmark of Ludwig’s angina. C. Associated with sialolithiasis False. Ludwig’s angina is not typically caused by sialolithiasis. The most common cause is a dental infection, especially from second or third mandibular molars. While sialadenitis due to sialolithiasis can cause swelling, it rarely leads to Ludwig’s angina D. Bilateral lymphadenopathy may occur True. The infection is typically bilateral and may involve lymph nodes, though lymphadenopathy is not always prominent. E. Swelling and erythema below the chin True. One of the classic findings — cellulitis of the submental region — often presents with tense, brawny swelling and redness below the chin.

questions.text: Trotter’s triad in nasopharyngeal carcinoma comprises?
questions.solution: A, C , D • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma occurs in fossa of rosenmuller. • It presents with totter’s triad which includes: glue ear + 5th nerve involvement + 10th nerve involvement • Glue ear causes unilateral conductive deafness. 5th nerve involvement causes ear pain and 10th nerve involvement leads to palatal palsy.

questions.text: Feature(s) of petrous apicitis include(s)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, C And D) • Petrous apicitis is one of the complications of CSOM. It presents with gradenigo triad • Gradenigo triad involves: ear discharge, 5th nerve palsy, 6th nerve palsy

questions.text: True regarding squamous cell carcinoma of larynx is/are? A. Most common type of laryngeal cancer B. Seen exclusively in smokers C. Associated with HPV 16 and 18 D. Change in voice quality is the most common complaint E. Subglottic cancers need radiotherapy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Most common type of laryngeal cancer Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) accounts for over 90% of all laryngeal cancers, making it the most common type. C. Associated with HPV 16 and 18 While smoking and alcohol are the primary risk factors, HPV (particularly types 16 and 18) has been linked to a subset of laryngeal SCCs, especially in non-smokers. D. Change in voice quality is the most common complaint Hoarseness is the most frequent presenting symptom, particularly in glottic cancers (where the vocal cords are involved). Incorrect Options: B. Seen exclusively in smokers While smoking is the major risk factor, laryngeal SCC can also occur in non-smokers, especially those with HPV infection, alcohol use, or GERD. E. Subglottic cancers need radiotherapy • Subglottic cancers are rare (<5% of laryngeal cancers). Treatment depends on stage: • Early-stage: Surgery (e.g., tracheal resection) or radiotherapy • Advanced-stage: Combined surgery (laryngectomy) + radiotherapy/chemoradiation • Radiotherapy alone is not always the first choice.

questions.text: Hearing loss is a symptom in which among the following disorders? A. Acoustic neuroma B. Meniere’s disease C. Vestibular neuritis D. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A. Acoustic neuroma Also called vestibular schwannoma. Causes progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss along with tinnitus and imbalance. B. Meniere’s disease Also presents with fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo. This is also a correct option, so if multiple correct answers are allowed, it should be included. Incorrect: C. Vestibular neuritis Causes vertigo without hearing loss. Involves only the vestibular portion of CN VIII. D. BPPV Causes positional vertigo due to dislodged otoliths but does not affect hearing.

questions.text: X-ray water’s view is for which sinus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Maxillary sinus – water’s view Ethmoid and frontal sinus – cadwell’s view Sphenoid sinus – lateral view, water’s view with open mouth (posterior ethmoid sinus is never seen on water’s view) Sphenoid sinus and posterior ethmoid sinus- basal veiw Water's view witj open mouth is called Pierre's view

questions.text: Referred pain of tonsillitis is carried by which of the following nerve?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tonsillar bed contains IX nerve ie glossopharyngeal nerve. Glossopharyngeal neurtis is an indication for tonsillectomy. Tonsillectomy is contra-indicated in epidemic of polio. Bed of Tonsil Image

questions.text: Nasopharyngeal chordoma originates from?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nasopharyngeal carcinoma originates from fossa of rosenmuller. Nasopharyngeal chordoma originates from notchord

questions.text: Which of the following is tensor of vocal cord:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) One liners on laryngeal muscles • Cricothyroid muscle is the tensor of vocal cord. • All muscles of vocal chord are supplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve except cricothyrioid. This is supplied by external branch of superior laryngeal nerve. • Posterior cricoarytenoid is the single abductor. Hence this is known as safety muscle of larynx.

choices.text: A patient of vocal cord palsy scheduled for thyroplasty
A patient of caner larynx scheduled for laryngectomy

questions.text: In which of the following case high-level tracheostomy is preferred?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A patient of cancer larynx scheduled for laryngectomy. A high-level tracheostomy is typically performed in patients who are undergoing laryngectomy (surgical removal of the larynx). This procedure is done to ensure that the patient can breathe through the tracheostomy after the larynx is removed. The tracheostomy is placed high in the neck, usually above the level of the stoma (opening) created during the laryngectomy, to help with respiratory function and maintain airway patency following the procedure. It is particularly beneficial in cases where the airway is at risk due to the removal of the vocal cords and laryngeal structures. Incorrect Options: (A) Foreign body obstruction in trachea A low tracheostomy or an emergency cricothyroidotomy would be more appropriate for managing airway obstruction caused by a foreign body in the trachea. A high-level tracheostomy would not be typically preferred for this type of acute obstruction. (B) A patient of vocal cord palsy scheduled for thyroplasty Thyroplasty is a procedure done to improve vocal cord function in patients with vocal cord paralysis, typically involving surgical alteration of the thyroid cartilage. This is not an indication for a high-level tracheostomy, as the procedure does not involve the removal of the larynx, and airway management is usually handled with standard intubation or tracheostomy at a lower level if needed. (D) A child with acute epiglottitis Acute epiglottitis involves inflammation and potential obstruction of the supraglottic structures, but high-level tracheostomy is not commonly the procedure of choice. In such cases, endotracheal intubation or, if necessary, a low tracheostomy may be performed. The airway management focuses on securing the airway as quickly as possible, usually in a lower, safer region.

questions.text: Electrode array in a patient of brain stem implant is placed in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Hearing aids preferred in conductive deafness. • Cochlear implants preferred in sensory deafness. • Brainstem implants are preffered in neural deafness. Electrode placement: Scala tympani is for cochlear implant. Lateral recess of fourth ventricle is for brain stem implant

questions.text: True in skull base osteomyelitis, except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Skull base osteomyelitis is malignant otitis externa. Predisposing factor is diabetes. Most common oraganism is pseudomonas. Presentation : ear discharge with normal tympanic membrane, granulation in EAC, facial nerve palsy. Diagnostic is Tc99 scan and prognostic scan is gallium scan. ESR can also be used in prognosis, ESR comes down within 2 weeks if patient is responding. Treatment is third gen cephalosporins.

questions.text: The complications of adenoidectomy include all of the following except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Blocked nose produces hyponasality. • Velopharyngeal insufficiency produces hypernasality. • Adenoidectomy produces hypernasality

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is seen in which of the following lesions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Supra glottic Inspiratory stridor is a high-pitched sound during inhalation and is usually indicative of an obstruction in the upper airway. This includes areas like the supraglottic region, which is the area above the vocal cords. Supraglottic lesions (e.g., tumors, infections, swelling) cause inspiratory stridor because they obstruct the airway before the vocal cords, making it harder for air to enter the trachea during inspiration. Incorrect Options: (B) Subglottic Subglottic lesions typically cause expiratory stridor because the obstruction is below the vocal cords. This creates difficulty in exhaling air out of the trachea. Subglottic stenosis or other issues below the vocal cords will result in expiratory rather than inspiratory stridor. (C) Tracheal Lesions in the trachea (such as tracheal stenosis or tumors) can cause both inspiratory and expiratory stridor depending on the location of the obstruction. The stridor may be biphasic (heard during both inhalation and exhalation), but typically, inspiratory stridor is not the hallmark symptom unless the lesion is specifically in the upper trachea near the vocal cords. (D) Bronchial Bronchial obstructions affect the lower airways (below the trachea), and they often lead to symptoms like wheezing or difficulty breathing but not typically inspiratory stridor. Bronchial lesions cause more of an expiratory or wheezing sound due to obstruction of airflow in the bronchi.

questions.text: Identify the lesion on vocal cord shown
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Laryngeal Papillomatosis also called as Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis. It is an acquired condition with Bimodal age occurrence. - Caused by 6, 11 human Papilloma virus . - Juvenile Laryngeal Papillomatosis is more common than Adult Laryngeal Papillomatosis. - Juvenile Laryngeal Papillomatosis in infants having H/O if vaginal delivery and multiple Papilloma in true vocal cord. - Adult Laryngeal Papillomatosis have single papillloma in true vocal cord. These growths can lead to vocal cord damage and airway problems. Because the virus is in the tissue, respiratory papillomas tend to reoccur even after they are removed. Treatment is laser resection of tumours. Post operative treatment: Alpha interferon immunomodulator - Bevacizumab ( reduces angiogenesis) - Cedofovir Prevented by vaccination for mother's - Cervarix , Gardasil-9

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) multiple TM perforations

questions.text: Most common site of branchial cyst is?
questions.solution: Commonest site of Branchial Cyst is between upper 1/3rd and lower 2/3rd of sternocleidomastoid on its anterior border Commonest site of Branchial fistula is at the junction of upper 2/3rd and lower 1/3rd of sternocleidomastoid at the anterior border of sternocleidomastoid muscle. Branchial Cyst Develops from the vestigial remnants of 2nd branchial cleft Lined by squamous epithelium Contains thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals Cyst usually presents in the upper neck in early or middle adulthood Found at the junction of upper third and middle third of the SCM muscle at its anterior border Fluctuant swelling that may transilluminate and is often soft in its early stages. USG and FNAC aid diagnosis Treatment is by complete excision
